News and developments from Justia and the tech world -----
February 2018
 

Welcome to the February 2018 edition of 
the Justia monthly newsletter!

Get an inside look at new developments in the online marketing world, keep up with the latest social media trends, and hear about what’s happening at the JUSTIA offices.

FEATURED NEWS

The Collaborative Law Firm Part II: Multi-User Chat

There are many communication options beyond traditional office memos, email, and telephones. In a previous post, we discussed instant message services, which have certain advantages and disadvantages for professional teams. In this post, we compare several team-based chat applications that are specifically designed to facilitate communication within and among teams in organizations of various sizes. We review a few of the most popular, and most feature-rich applications in this category and describe the pros and cons of each.

Tech News

Net Neutrality Gaining Steam in State Legislatures After FCC Repeal

In a highly controversial move, the FCC in December repealed “net neutrality” rules governing internet service providers. In response, state legislators in Nebraska and California are proposing their own net neutrality laws to regulate ISPs within those states. Officials in other states, such as New York, have filed lawsuits against the FCC over the repeal of the rules. Although net neutrality is portrayed as a politically divisive issue in government, polls show that majorities of both Democratic and Republican voters support net neutrality rules.

Summary: The FISA Amendments Reauthorization Act of 2017

In January, the Senate voted to extend the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) for six more years, and President Trump signed the bill into law. In an official statement, President Trump described the bill as allowing the intelligence community to “collect critical intelligence on international terrorists, weapons proliferators, and other important foreign intelligence targets” outside of the US. This article summarizes some of the changes that this bill made to existing law.

Flurry of Lawsuits Filed to Fight Repeal of Net Neutrality

While some states are considering their own net neutrality laws (see above article) in response to the FCC’s repeal of federal net neutrality rules, other states (and some overlapping) are resorting to litigation. A lawsuit filed by 21 state attorneys general argues that the repeal of net neutrality rules was “arbitrary and capricious,” in violation of federal law, and a reversal of the agency’s longstanding policy of preventing ISPs from blocking or charging websites for faster delivery of content to consumers. Among those states filing lawsuits are California, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, and Oregon.

Amazon Releases List of Metro Areas Being Considered for Its Second HQ

Following up on its announcement that it was accepting bids for a location for a second headquarters, Amazon recently announced the list of metropolitan areas that were in the running. These 20 candidates range from large cities such as Los Angeles, Dallas, and Atlanta, to smaller communities like Pittsburgh, Raleigh, and Nashville. Among those that didn’t make the cut are Baltimore, Birmingham, Houston, Phoenix, Portland, and San Francisco.

Google and Twitter Face More Questions in Washington Over Russian Interference

Facing scrutiny from lawmakers, Twitter plans to notify users who may have been exposed to Russian propaganda during the 2016 presidential election. Google, however, has stated that it would be too difficult to notify its users of potential exposure to misinformation from Russian sources.

SEO News

How Independent Reviews Influence Google’s Trust in Your Brand

Online reviews have a huge impact on the decision making process of consumers, from their choice of what to click on to their ultimate decision of whom to hire or what to buy. As a result, Google is increasingly giving weight to legitimate consumer reviews. This article describes a number of ways that you can encourage your clients to write reviews so that you can build Google’s trust in your brand.

Google Adds AMP Testing Tool to Search Results

In 2016, Google launched its AMP testing tool as part of the Search Console (formerly Webmaster Tools). In January 2018, it released its most significant update to that tool—AMP testing directly in search results. As with the original tool, users can test the validity of your AMP markup and structured data on the page related to AMP. Users are also able to submit an AMP to Google’s index after testing it, as well as view an AMP’s raw source code.

Google My Business Videos Now Live

In a change that was much anticipated, Google My Business (GMB) now allows business owners to upload videos up to 30 seconds in length to their listings. The videos will appear in the “Overview” tab of the Google My Business Dashboard. Customer-uploaded videos can be found in the “Customer” tab, while business-uploaded videos will be in the “By Owner” tab. Once live, they will display where local photos do, on maps and local search listings.

The Google Speed Update: Page Speed Will Become a Factor in Mobile Search

Google announced in January on the Google Webmaster Central Blog that a new mobile ranking update will be coming in July 2018. Dubbed the “Speed Update,” this ranking change specifically focuses on mobile page speed, but it will apply only to mobile search results; desktop search results will still use the existing desktop page speed ranking factor from the 2010 update. Websites that do not have AMP versions may suffer after this update, as Google stated that the speed factor is based on “real world” results—what a user can expect to get when they tap the result.

Social Media News

Twitter Asserts That It Won’t Ban Trump Because He’s a World Leader

Despite calls for Twitter to ban President Trump’s account for his choice to publicly antagonize foreign adversaries, the social media company opted to sidestep the question of whether the US president’s account had violated its terms of service. In a blog post response, Twitter did not mention President Trump by name when it addressed its decision. Instead, the company merely stated that world leaders should have a home on its social media platform, regardless of whether they violate Twitter’s terms of service.

Facebook is Changing. What Does That Mean for Your News Feed?

Facebook users may notice an overhaul in the appearance of their News Feeds due to recent changes in the way that Facebook ranks posts, videos, and photos. The aim, according to the social media company, is to prioritize the content that a user’s friends and family share over ads from brands and publications. While this is meant to make the social network more personalized and meaningful for users, third-party organizations may start noticing that the visibility of their digital marketing efforts has been scaled back—with the exception of those posts that a user’s Facebook connections find engaging.

Facebook Agrees to Take a Deeper Look Into Russian Brexit Involvement

Facebook has indicated that it will launch a more comprehensive investigation as to whether any Russian meddling associated with the 2016 Brexit referendum vote in the United Kingdom took place on its platform. This announcement comes after the chair of a parliamentary committee criticized Facebook for failing to cooperate with its wide-reaching fake news enquiry. It remains unclear whether Twitter will also acquiesce and launch its own Brexit-related fake news investigation.

Facebook “Watch Party” Lets Groups View Videos Simultaneously

Active, rather than passive, content consumption continues to be the recent focus of newly launched Facebook features. “Watch Party” is the latest such feature, and it allows Group admins to choose any video publicly available on Facebook and share it with their group’s members simultaneously with a comment reel. This is intended to foster a “shared viewing experience.” Watch Party offers a more intimate means of fostering discussion than live, public videos on Facebook, as smaller Groups tend not to generate as many thousands of rapid-fire comments and can allow for more focused, meaningful discussions.

Facebook Finally Pays Up for Music, Cutting In on YouTube

Digital marketers may be wondering what types of content will continue to be visible on Facebook after its recent News Feed update. Its new music industry partnership may offer some insight with many speculating about a heightened focus on entertainment content. The partnership involves a deal with companies representing various worldwide music publishers, songwriters, and performers. The official Facebook announcement seems to imply the partnership will be aimed at enriching Facebook users’ overall experience on its social media platform.

How Facebook’s Latest Changes Affect Influencers and The Future of Social Media Marketing

Digital marketers are worried about their future on Facebook in light of the News Feed algorithm change. However, are their concerns warranted? According to a Forbes opinion, social influencers stand to benefit from this change most of all when less material from media outlets is organically appearing on Facebook users’ feeds. This may indeed affect the visibility of business ads—or, in the alternative, encourage them to adapt.

Google App Featuring Matching Selfies to Art is Blocked in Two States With Strict Biometrics Laws

Individuals living in Illinois and Texas won’t have access to a popular, new feature on the Google Arts & Culture app that matches selfies to artwork in upwards of 1,200 museums. Due to strict state laws regulating to the collection of “face geometry” and other data of a biometric nature, Google has chosen to err on the side of caution and bar the app feature in both states. Outside the US, the feature has also been blocked, likely as a result of European privacy laws.

Legal Industry News

3 Days Into New Job, Philadelphia DA Krasner Fires 31 Staff Members

Larry Krasner, who was recently elected District Attorney of Philadelphia, made waves by firing 31 of the office’s approximately 600 staff members shortly after beginning the job. Krasner, whose history as a civil rights lawyer includes representing parties against the government in a number of lawsuits, as well as defending activists in legal trouble, has stated his intention to implement criminal justice reform while in office. A spokesman indicated that the firings reflected Krasner’s aim to take the office in a different direction.

Recap: Reboot Your Firm for 2018

The end of 2017 saw Atlanta Legal Tech host its inaugural Reboot Your Firm conference. Targeted toward solo and small firms, the event focused on topics including legal ethics, improving efficiency, and embracing technology in your practice.

Top Three Questions 2018 Will Answer for IP Lawyers

This column offers insights into three questions regarding IP law that may be answered during the coming year. Specifically, (1) the Supreme Court is expected to decide the Oil States case regarding the constitutionality of the patent review procedures implemented under the America Invents Act, (2) 2018 may bring more clarity as to whether the Trump administration will adopt a pro-IP owner stance, and (3) the prospective renegotiation of US trade deals will likely have a significant impact on IP issues.

Less Than Half of Recent Law Grads Had ‘Good Jobs’ Waiting After Graduation, Report Says

A recent report examining the long-term outcomes of having a law degree indicated that over half of JD holders would go to law school again if given the choice, though less than half of that group felt their degree was worth the cost, especially if they graduated recently. Less than half of JD holders who finished law school during the recession years of 2009-2017 had “good jobs” lined up after graduation, and over one quarter of those grads reported that it took them more than a year to find one.

Surpassing Expectations, Defying Labels: Life as a Deaf Attorney and Working Mother

As part of its Making It Work column, which focuses on mothers working in law, the ABA Journal profiled Boies, Schiller & Flexner litigation partner Melissa Felder Zappala. Defying a childhood prognosis that she would likely never learn to speak and wouldn’t read above a fourth grade level due to the fact that she was deaf, Zappala has excelled in a demanding profession while also prioritizing with her family life. In this article she outlines the key factors that have shaped her trajectory, and that help her continue to strive for balance.

Millennial Lawyers Are Forging Their Own Paths--And It’s Wrong to Call Them Lazy

Dispelling stereotypes of entitlement and laziness, millennials in the legal profession are finding professional success and personal fulfillment by venturing out on their own and staying true to their beliefs. This article seeks to debunk common myths regarding millennials in the workforce, and profiles a number of recent law grads whose tech-savvy, flexible, and hard-working approach is propelling their careers forward and redefining what it means to be part of their generation in the legal world.
